<FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="1">progress to date against goals, amounts presented in Column (i)&nbsp;for the 2008-2009 and 2007-2009 performance cycles are presented at the threshold levels
set at the start of the applicable performance cycles. The actual number of PSUs earned, if any, will be determined at the end of each performance cycle and may be more or less than the amount reflected in Column (i). </FONT></P></TD></TR></TABLE>
<P STYLE="font-size:6px;margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">&nbsp;</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">

</FONT></TD></TR></TABLE> <P STYLE="font-size:6px;margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">&nbsp;</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">

<TD ALIGN="left" VALIGN="top"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="1">Column (j)&nbsp;contains the value of PSUs reported in Column (i)&nbsp;using the price per share of our Common Stock of $34.74, the closing price of our Common Stock on the New York
Stock Exchange on December&nbsp;31, 2008, the last trading day of 2008. </FONT></TD></TR></TABLE> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P>
 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">64 </FONT></P>


<p Style='page-break-before:always'>
<HR  SIZE="3" COLOR="#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">


 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P>
 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><B><A NAME="toc83500_19"></A>Option Exercises and Stock Vested </B></FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">The following table and explanatory footnotes provide information with regard to amounts paid to or received by our named executive officers during 2008 as a result of
the exercise of stock options or the vesting of stock awards. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><B>Option Exercises and Stock Vested </B></FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><B>2008 </B></FONT></P> <P STYLE="font-size:12px;margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">&nbsp;</P>
<TABLE CELLSPACING="0" CELLPADDING="0" WIDTH="100%" BORDER="0" ALIGN="center">

<TR>
<TD WIDTH="20%"></TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom" WIDTH="1%"></TD>

December&nbsp;31, 2008 that were determined by the Committee to be earned. In accordance with the PSU award, each PSU represents one share of our Common Stock valued at $34.74, the December&nbsp;31, 2008 closing price of our Common Stock. Amounts
shown in Column (e)&nbsp;for the 2003-2005 PSUs include cash credits in lieu of dividends and interest earned on the dividend credits since the end of the performance period on December&nbsp;31, 2005. </FONT></TD></TR></TABLE> <P
STYLE="font-size:6px;margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">&nbsp;</P>

<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="3%" VALIGN="top" ALIGN="left"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="1">(3)</FONT></TD>
<TD ALIGN="left" VALIGN="top"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="1">On April&nbsp;2, 2008, Mr.&nbsp;West received 22,000 shares of Common Stock as payment of the RSU award granted to him in 2007. The value of the shares distributed to Mr.&nbsp;West
was $863,280. Required tax withholdings were deducted from the shares distributed. Mr.&nbsp;West also received a cash payment of $13,090 equivalent to dividends that would have been earned on these RSUs had he held Common Stock instead of RSUs since
the grant date in 2007. Mr.&nbsp;West utilized the net cash received in lieu of dividends to partially offset taxes owed on the shares distributed, resulting in distribution of 15,643 shares of the Company&#146;s Common Stock to Mr.&nbsp;West.
Column (e)&nbsp;reflects the market value of the 22,000 shares on the payment date and the cash equivalent of dividends received by Mr.&nbsp;West. </FONT></TD></TR></TABLE> <P STYLE="font-size:6px;margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">&nbsp;</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="3%" VALIGN="top" ALIGN="left"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="1">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD ALIGN="left" VALIGN="top"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="1">Mr.&nbsp;West elected to receive the shares that were payable to him from the 2003-2005 PSU cycle in January 2009, following vesting on December&nbsp;31, 2008. The gross number of
shares payable to him, 18,000, was reduced by required tax withholdings, resulting in disbursement of 10,695 shares of the Company&#146;s Common Stock to Mr.&nbsp;West. The amount in Column (e)&nbsp;reflects the gross value of the PSUs and $64,114
of cash credits in lieu of dividends and interest on those cash credits that would have been earned on the PSUs during the 2005-2008 vesting period had the PSUs been shares of Common Stock. </FONT></TD></TR></TABLE> <P
STYLE="font-size:6px;margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">&nbsp;</P>

<TD ALIGN="left" VALIGN="top"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="1">On May&nbsp;1, 2008, Mr.&nbsp;Alfonso received 2,557 shares of Common Stock as payment upon vesting of a pro rata portion of the RSU award granted to him in 2007. In addition,
Mr.&nbsp;Alfonso received a cash payment of $2,973, equivalent to dividends that would have been earned on these RSUs had he held Common Stock instead of RSUs during the vesting </FONT></TD></TR></TABLE> <P
STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P>
 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">65 </FONT></P>


<p Style='page-break-before:always'>
<HR  SIZE="3" COLOR="#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">

 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="3%"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD ALIGN="left" VALIGN="top"> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:1px; margin-left:0%">
<FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="1">period. Mr.&nbsp;Alfonso utilized the net cash received in lieu of dividends on the RSUs and liquidated 729 RSUs to meet tax obligations, resulting in his
receipt of 1,828 shares of the Company&#146;s Common Stock. </FONT></P></TD></TR></TABLE> <P STYLE="font-size:6px;margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">&nbsp;</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="3%" VALIGN="top" ALIGN="left"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="1">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD ALIGN="left" VALIGN="top"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="1">On July&nbsp;17, 2008, 3,000 RSUs awarded to Mr.&nbsp;Alfonso in 2006 vested. Mr.&nbsp;Alfonso elected to defer 75% of this award payment and receive immediate payment in shares of
the Company&#146;s Common Stock for the remaining 25%. On the vesting date of these RSUs, Mr.&nbsp;Alfonso received a cash payment of $6,810, equivalent to dividends that would have been earned on these RSUs had he held Common Stock instead of RSUs
during the vesting period. Mr.&nbsp;Alfonso utilized the net cash received in lieu of dividends on the RSUs designated for deferral to meet tax obligations on the deferred portion of his award, resulting in deferral of 2,250 shares. Based on
Mr.&nbsp;Alfonso&#146;s deferral election, these 2,250 RSUs will be paid as shares of Common Stock, net of applicable taxes in 2013. Mr.&nbsp;Alfonso utilized the remaining net cash received in lieu of dividends on the RSUs designated for deferral
along with the net cash received in lieu of dividends on the RSUs designated for immediate payment in shares and liquidated 125 RSUs to meet tax obligations on the portion designated for immediate payment, resulting in his receipt of 625 shares of
the Company&#146;s Common Stock. </FONT></TD></TR></TABLE> <P STYLE="font-size:6px;margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">&nbsp;</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="3%" VALIGN="top" ALIGN="left"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="1">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD ALIGN="left" VALIGN="top"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="1">On September&nbsp;1, 2008, 500 RSUs awarded to Mr.&nbsp;Alfonso in 2006 vested. Mr.&nbsp;Alfonso elected to defer 75% of this award payment and receive immediate payment in shares
of the Company&#146;s Common Stock for the remaining 25%. On the vesting date of these RSUs, Mr.&nbsp;Alfonso received a cash payment of $1,149, equivalent to dividends that would have been earned on these RSUs had he held Common Stock instead of
RSUs during the vesting period. Mr.&nbsp;Alfonso utilized the net cash received in lieu of dividends on the RSUs designated for deferral to meet tax obligations on the deferred portion of his award, resulting in deferral of 375 shares. Based on
Mr.&nbsp;Alfonso&#146;s deferral election, these 375 RSUs will be paid as shares of Common Stock, net of applicable taxes in 2010. Mr.&nbsp;Alfonso utilized the remaining net cash received in lieu of dividends on the RSUs designated for deferral
along with the net cash received in lieu of dividends on the RSUs designated for immediate payment in shares and liquidated 22 RSUs to meet tax obligations on the portion designated for immediate payment, resulting in his receipt of 103 shares of
the Company&#146;s Common Stock. </FONT></TD></TR></TABLE> <P STYLE="font-size:6px;margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">&nbsp;</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="3%" VALIGN="top" ALIGN="left"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="1">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD ALIGN="left" VALIGN="top"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="1">The value of the RSUs paid to or deferred by Mr.&nbsp;Alfonso was based on the closing price of the Company&#146;s Common Stock on the trading day prescribed by the Incentive Plan.
Required tax withholdings were deducted from all payments. Column (e)&nbsp;reflects the value of the 6,057 shares realized by Mr.&nbsp;Alfonso as the result of vesting of RSUs in 2008 and the cash equivalent of dividends payable on the RSUs vesting
in 2008. </FONT></TD></TR></TABLE> <P STYLE="font-size:6px;margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">&nbsp;</P>

<TR>
<TD WIDTH="3%" VALIGN="top" ALIGN="left"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="1">(5)</FONT></TD>
<TD ALIGN="left" VALIGN="top"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="1">On August&nbsp;8, 2008, Mr.&nbsp;Bilbrey received 1,250 shares of Common Stock as payment upon vesting of a pro rata portion of the RSU awards granted to him in 2005.
Mr.&nbsp;Bilbrey elected to receive payment for his RSUs in cash and received a gross payment of $50,600. On the vesting date of these RSUs, Mr.&nbsp;Bilbrey also received a cash payment of $4,063, equivalent to dividends that would have been earned
on the RSUs had he held Common Stock instead of RSUs during the vesting period. Required tax withholdings were deducted from both payments. Column (e)&nbsp;reflects the market value of the 1,250 shares on the vesting date and the cash equivalent of
dividends paid on the vesting date. </FONT></TD></TR></TABLE> <P STYLE="font-size:6px;margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">&nbsp;</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="3%" VALIGN="top" ALIGN="left"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="1">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD ALIGN="left" VALIGN="top"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="1">Mr.&nbsp;Bilbrey elected to receive 50% of the shares payable to him from the 2003-2005 PSU cycle in January 2009, following vesting on December&nbsp;31, 2008. The gross number of
shares payable to him, 7,500, was reduced by required tax withholdings, resulting in distribution of 5,161 shares of the Company&#146;s Common Stock to Mr.&nbsp;Bilbrey. Mr.&nbsp;Bilbrey deferred the remaining 50% of the shares payable to him from
the 2003-2005 PSU cycle and accordingly 7,500 shares were credited to his deferred compensation account in January 2009. Based on Mr.&nbsp;Bilbrey&#146;s deferral election, these 7,500 PSUs will be paid as shares of Common Stock, net of applicable
taxes, following Mr.&nbsp;Bilbrey&#146;s separation from service subject to the restrictions of Internal Revenue Code section 409A, or &#147;section 409A.&#148; The amount in Column (e)&nbsp;reflects the gross value of the 15,000 PSUs and $53,280 of
credits in lieu of dividends and interest on those cash credits that would have been earned on the PSUs during the 2005-2008 vesting period had the PSUs been shares of Common Stock. All of the cash credits in lieu of dividends and interest on those
cash credits were paid to Mr.&nbsp;Bilbrey, net of required tax withholdings, in January 2009. As per the conditions of our Deferred Compensation Plan, no portion of the cash credits were permitted to be deferred. </FONT></TD></TR></TABLE> <P
STYLE="font-size:6px;margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">&nbsp;</P>

have been earned on these RSUs had he held Common Stock instead of RSUs during the vesting period. Mr.&nbsp;Snyder utilized the net cash received in lieu of dividends on the RSUs and liquidated 1,982 RSUs to meet tax obligations, resulting in his
receipt of 3,018 shares of the Company&#146;s Common Stock. Column (e)&nbsp;reflects the market value of the 5,000 shares on the vesting date and the cash equivalent of dividends paid on the vesting date. </FONT></TD></TR></TABLE> <P

<p Style='page-break-before:always'>
<HR  SIZE="3" COLOR="#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">


 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P>

<FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="1">would have been earned on these RSUs had she held Common Stock instead of RSUs during the vesting period. Ms.&nbsp;Buck utilized the net cash received in
lieu of dividends and liquidated 34 RSUs to meet the tax obligations on the RSUs designated for deferral, resulting in deferral of 1,632 shares. </FONT></P></TD></TR></TABLE> <P STYLE="font-size:6px;margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">&nbsp;</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="3%" VALIGN="top" ALIGN="left"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="1">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD ALIGN="left" VALIGN="top"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="1">On February&nbsp;8, 2008, 625 RSUs awarded to Ms.&nbsp;Buck in 2007 vested. Ms.&nbsp;Buck elected to defer 100% of the award. On the vesting date of these RSUs, Ms.&nbsp;Buck also
received a cash payment of $709, equivalent to dividends that would have been earned on these RSUs had she held Common Stock instead of RSUs during the vesting period. Ms.&nbsp;Buck utilized the net cash received in lieu of dividends to meet the tax
obligations on the RSUs designated for deferral, resulting in deferral of the full 625 RSUs. </FONT></TD></TR></TABLE> <P STYLE="font-size:6px;margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">&nbsp;</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="3%" VALIGN="top" ALIGN="left"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="1">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD ALIGN="left" VALIGN="top"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="1">On May&nbsp;1, 2008, 2,508 RSUs awarded to Ms.&nbsp;Buck in 2007 vested. Ms.&nbsp;Buck elected to defer 100% of the award. On the vesting date of these RSUs, Ms.&nbsp;Buck also

<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="3%" VALIGN="top" ALIGN="left"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="1">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD ALIGN="left" VALIGN="top"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="1">The value of the RSUs deferred by Ms.&nbsp;Buck was based on the closing price of the Company&#146;s Common Stock on the trading day prescribed by the Incentive Plan. Required tax
withholdings were deducted from all payments. Column (e)&nbsp;reflects the value of the 4,799 shares realized by Ms.&nbsp;Buck as the result of vesting of RSUs in 2008 and the cash equivalent of dividends payable on the RSUs vesting in 2008. Based
on Ms.&nbsp;Buck&#146;s deferral elections, the 4,765 RSUs that vested in 2008 and were deferred into the Company&#146;s Deferred Compensation Plan will be paid as shares of Common Stock, net of applicable taxes, following Ms.&nbsp;Buck&#146;s
separation from service subject to the restrictions of section&nbsp;409A. </FONT></TD></TR></TABLE> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><B><A NAME="toc83500_20"></A>Pension Benefits </B></FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Each of the named executive officers is a participant in our tax-qualified defined benefit pension plan and is fully vested in his or her benefit under that plan. All,
except Mr.&nbsp;Alfonso, were eligible to participate in our non-qualified defined benefit Supplemental Executive Retirement Plan, or DB SERP. With the exception of Mr.&nbsp;West, whose eligibility for a DB SERP benefit is described below, no
benefit is payable under the DB SERP if the executive officer terminates employment prior to age 55 or if he or she does not have five years of service with the Company. As of December&nbsp;31, 2008, Mr.&nbsp;Snyder had attained age 55 with five
years of service. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">The combination of the tax-qualified and DB SERP plans was designed to provide a benefit on retirement at or after reaching age 60 based
on a joint and survivor annuity equal to 55% of final average compensation for an executive officer with 15 or more years of service (reduced pro rata for each year of service under 15). Effective January&nbsp;1, 2007, the benefit payable under the
DB&nbsp;SERP to an executive officer who was age 50 or over as of January&nbsp;1, 2007 was reduced by 10%, and the benefit payable to an executive officer who had not attained age 50 as of January&nbsp;1, 2007, was reduced by 20%. The benefits
payable to Messrs. Bilbrey and Snyder were reduced by 10% and the benefits payable to Mr.&nbsp;West and Ms.&nbsp;Buck were reduced by 20%. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Final average
compensation is calculated as the sum of (i)&nbsp;the average of the highest three calendar years of base salary paid over the last five years of employment with the Company and (ii)&nbsp;the average of the highest three annual AIP awards for the
last five years of employment with the Company, whether received or deferred. The benefit accrued under the DB SERP is payable upon retirement in a lump sum, life annuity with 50% benefit continuation to the participant&#146;s surviving spouse or
payment may be deferred in accordance with the provisions of the Company&#146;s Deferred Compensation Plan. The lump sum is equal to the actuarial present value of the joint and survivor pension earned, reduced by the lump sum value of the benefits
to be paid under the tax-qualified defined benefit pension plan and the value of the executive&#146;s Social Security benefits. If the executive officer terminates employment after age 55 but before age 60, the benefit is reduced for early
retirement at a rate of 5%&nbsp;per year for the period until the executive would have turned 60. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Our employment agreement with Mr.&nbsp;West contains
special provisions relating to the vesting of his benefit under the DB SERP. Under the employment agreement, Mr.&nbsp;West was fully vested in </FONT>
</P>
 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">67 </FONT></P>


<p Style='page-break-before:always'>
<HR  SIZE="3" COLOR="#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">

 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">
<FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">his accrued DB SERP benefit as of January&nbsp;2, 2008. If Mr.&nbsp;West terminates employment prior to age 60, the benefit payable upon termination is
reduced for early retirement at a rate of 5%&nbsp;per year for the period between termination and attainment of age 60. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px;padding-bottom:3px;line-height:95%; vertical-align:top"><FONT
FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">On June&nbsp;3, 2008, the Committee approved a special provision for the DB SERP benefit of Mr.&nbsp;Snyder to recognize his continuing service with the Company past his 60</FONT><FONT FACE="Times New Roman"
SIZE="1"><SUP>th</SUP></FONT><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"> birthday. To protect against the erosion of the lump sum value of his benefit, the provision provides that Mr.&nbsp;Snyder will receive a lump sum value at least as large as
$5,290,335, which was the estimated amount he would have received had he retired on December&nbsp;31, 2008. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">The Compensation Limit Replacement Plan, or
CLRP, provides eligible participants the defined benefit he or she would have earned under our tax-qualified defined benefit pension plan were it not for the legal limitation on compensation used to determine benefits. An executive officer who is a
participant in DB SERP is not eligible to participate in the CLRP, unless he or she (i)&nbsp;ceases to be designated by the Committee as eligible to participate in the DB SERP prior to his or her termination of employment with the Company, or
(ii)&nbsp;has his or her employment involuntarily terminated by the Company, other than for Cause as defined in the DB SERP. Such executive officer would then become eligible to participate in the CLRP and to receive a benefit for all years in which
he or she would have been a participant of the CLRP, but for his or her designation by the Committee to be eligible to participate in the DB SERP. Executive officers who are eligible for both the DC SERP (described under Non-Qualified Deferred
Compensation below) and the tax-qualified defined benefit pension plan receive an additional contribution in the CLRP equal to 3% of their eligible earnings less the legal limitation on compensation. Upon separation, benefits under the CLRP are
payable in a single lump sum or may be deferred into the Deferred Compensation Plan. A participant is eligible for his or her CLRP benefit upon separation from service (subject to the provisions of section&nbsp;409A) after five years of service or
attaining age 55 (unless the participant is terminated for Cause). Payment is also made to the estate of a participant who dies prior to separation from service. Participants who become disabled are 100% vested in their benefit and continue to
accrue additional benefits for up to two additional years. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P>
 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">68 </FONT></P>


<p Style='page-break-before:always'>
<HR  SIZE="3" COLOR="#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">


 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P>
 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">The following table and explanatory footnotes provide information regarding the present value of benefits accrued
under the tax-qualified defined benefit pension plan, as applicable, and the DB&nbsp;SERP or CLRP for each named executive officer as of December&nbsp;31, 2008. The amounts shown for the DB SERP reflect the reduction for the present value of the
benefits under the tax-qualified defined benefit pension plan and Social Security benefits. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><B>Pension Benefits </B></FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="3"><B>2008 </B></FONT></P> <P STYLE="font-size:12px;margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">&nbsp;</P>

<TD VALIGN="bottom" STYLE="BORDER-RIGHT:1px solid #000000"> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Tax-Qualified Defined Benefit Pension Plan</FONT></P> <P

<TD VALIGN="bottom"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>

 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">69 </FONT></P>


<p Style='page-break-before:always'>
<HR  SIZE="3" COLOR="#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">

 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><B><A NAME="toc83500_21"></A>Non-Qualified
Deferred Compensation </B></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Our named executive officers are eligible to participate in The Hershey Company Deferred Compensation Plan. The Deferred
Compensation Plan is a non-qualified plan that permits participants to defer receipt of compensation otherwise payable to them. The Deferred Compensation Plan is intended to secure the goodwill and loyalty of participants by enabling them to defer
compensation when the participants deem it to be beneficial to do so and by providing a vehicle for the Company to provide, on a non-qualified basis, contributions which could not be made on the participants&#146; behalf to the tax-qualified 401(k)
Plan. The Company credits the Deferred Compensation Plan with a specified percentage of compensation for executive officers participating in the non-qualified defined contribution Supplemental Executive Retirement Plan, or DC SERP. </FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Our named executive officers may elect to defer payments to be received as a result of DB SERP, CLRP, AIP, PSU and RSU awards, but not stock options. Amounts deferred
are credited to the participant&#146;s account under the Deferred Compensation Plan. Amounts deferred are fully vested and will be paid at a future date or at termination of employment, as the participant may elect. </FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Payments are distributed in a lump sum or in annual installments of up to 15 years. All amounts are payable in a lump sum following a change in control. All elections
and payments under the Deferred Compensation Plan are subject to compliance with section&nbsp;409A which may limit elections and require a delay in payment of benefits in certain circumstances. </FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">While deferred, amounts are credited with &#147;earnings&#148; as if they were invested as the participant elects in one or more investment options available under the
Deferred Compensation Plan. The investment options under the Deferred Compensation Plan consist of investment in shares of our Common Stock or in mutual funds or other investments available to participants in our 401(k) Plan. The participants&#146;
accounts under the Deferred Compensation Plan will be adjusted daily, up or down, depending upon performance of the investment options elected. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Effective
January&nbsp;1, 2007, we began crediting the deferred compensation accounts of all employees, including the named executive officers, with the amount of employer matching contributions that exceed the limits established by the Internal Revenue
Service for contribution to the 401(k) Plan. These amounts are credited in the first quarter of the year after they are earned. As shown in the Notes to the Summary Compensation Table on page 58, these amounts are designated as &#147;Supplemental
401(k) match&#148; and are included as &#147;All Other Compensation&#148; in the year earned, but are included in Column (c)&nbsp;of the Non-Qualified Deferred Compensation table in the year credited. With the exception of Mr.&nbsp;Alfonso, the
named executive officers are fully vested in the Supplemental 401(k) match credits and will be paid at a future date or at termination of employment, as elected by the officer. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT
FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Effective July&nbsp;16, 2007, Mr.&nbsp;Alfonso was eligible to participate in our DC SERP, a part of the Deferred Compensation Plan. The DC SERP provides annual allocations to the Deferred Compensation Plan equal to a
percentage of compensation determined by the Committee in its sole discretion. In order to receive the annual DC SERP allocation, an executive officer must (i)&nbsp;defer in the 401(k) Plan the maximum amount allowed by the Company or IRS and
(ii)&nbsp;be employed on the last day of the plan year unless he or she terminates employment while at least age 55, retires, dies or becomes disabled. After completing five years of service with the Company, an executive officer is vested in 10%
increments based on his or her age. An executive age&nbsp;46 with five years of service is 10% vested and an executive age 55 with five years of service is 100% vested. Mr.&nbsp;Alfonso&#146;s annual DC SERP allocation is equal to 12.5% of his base
salary and AIP for the calendar year, whether paid or deferred. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P>
 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">70 </FONT></P>


<p Style='page-break-before:always'>
<HR  SIZE="3" COLOR="#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">

named executive officers during 2008 and the aggregate balance of the accounts as of December&nbsp;31, 2008. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><B>Non-Qualified Deferred
Compensation </B></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><B>2008 </B></FONT></P> <P STYLE="font-size:12px;margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">&nbsp;</P>

STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:1px" ALIGN="center"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="1"><B>($)</B></FONT></P></TD></TR>
<TR>
<TD VALIGN="bottom" ALIGN="center" STYLE="BORDER-LEFT:1px solid #000000; BORDER-BOTTOM:1px solid #000000; padding-left:8px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="1">(a)</FONT></TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom" STYLE="BORDER-LEFT:1px solid #000000; BORDER-BOTTOM:1px solid #000000"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom" ALIGN="center" STYLE="BORDER-RIGHT:1px solid #000000; BORDER-BOTTOM:1px solid #000000"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="1">(b)</FONT></TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom" STYLE="BORDER-BOTTOM:1px solid #000000"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>

 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">71 </FONT></P>


<p Style='page-break-before:always'>
<HR  SIZE="3" COLOR="#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">

 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><B><A NAME="toc83500_22"></A>Potential
Payments Upon Termination or Change in Control </B></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">We have entered into an employment agreement with Mr.&nbsp;West and maintain plans covering our
executive officers that will require us to provide incremental compensation in the event of involuntary termination of employment or a change in control. We describe these obligations below. </FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><I>Overview </I></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">We entered into an employment agreement with Mr.&nbsp;West
at the time of his promotion to the position of President in October 2007. The agreement has a term of three years and renews daily. The agreement provides for Mr.&nbsp;West&#146;s employment as our President and effective December&nbsp;1, 2007 as
President and Chief Executive Officer and contains provisions relating to his responsibilities, compensation, confidentiality, non-competition and non-solicitation commitments and agreements, and payments, if any, to be made to him upon termination
of employment. Mr.&nbsp;West and our other named executive officers participate in the Executive Benefits Protection Plan (Group 3A), or EBPP, amended and restated as of January&nbsp;1, 2009. The EBPP is intended to help us attract and retain
qualified executive employees and maintain a stable work environment by making a provision for the protection of covered executives in connection with a change in control of Hershey or termination of employment under certain circumstances.
</FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Each of our named executive officers also has entered into a participation agreement in connection with the receipt of long-term incentive compensation
awards such as stock options and PSUs. The participation agreement obligates the executive officer to not disclose or misuse our confidential and proprietary information. In addition, any executive officer eligible to receive benefits under the DB
SERP agrees that for three years after termination of employment for any reason, he or she will not join or otherwise become involved with a domestic or worldwide business that competes in any of our primary product lines. </FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Termination of employment and a change in control also impact PSUs, RSUs and stock option awards we have made, as well as benefits payable under our employee benefit
plans. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">The following narrative takes each termination of employment situation &#150; voluntary resignation, discharge for Cause, death, disability,
discharge without Cause, and resignation for Good Reason&nbsp;&#150; and a change in control of the Company, and describes the additional amounts, if any, that the Company would pay or provide to Ms.&nbsp;Buck and Messrs. West, Alfonso, Bilbrey, and
Snyder, or their beneficiaries as a result. The narrative below and the amounts shown reflect certain assumptions we have made in accordance with SEC rules. These assumptions are that the termination of employment or change in control occurred on
December&nbsp;31, 2008 and that the value of a share of our Common Stock on that day was $34.74, the closing price on the New York Stock Exchange on December&nbsp;31, 2008, the last trading day of 2008. </FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">In addition, in keeping with SEC rules, the following narrative and amounts do not include payments and benefits which are not enhanced by the termination of employment
or change in control. These payments and benefits include: </FONT></P> <P STYLE="font-size:12px;margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">&nbsp;</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="5%"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="2%" VALIGN="top" ALIGN="left"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">&#149;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="top"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD ALIGN="left" VALIGN="top"> <P ALIGN="left"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Benefits accrued under the Company&#146;s broad-based tax-qualified 401(k) Plan and tax-qualified defined benefit pension plan; </FONT></P></TD></TR></TABLE> <P
STYLE="font-size:2px;margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">&nbsp;</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="5%"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="2%" VALIGN="top" ALIGN="left"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">&#149;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="top"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD ALIGN="left" VALIGN="top"> <P ALIGN="left"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Accrued vacation pay, health plan continuation and other similar amounts payable when employment terminates under programs applicable to the Company&#146;s salaried
employees generally; </FONT></P></TD></TR></TABLE> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P>
 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">72 </FONT></P>


<p Style='page-break-before:always'>
<HR  SIZE="3" COLOR="#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">


 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P>

<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="5%"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="2%" VALIGN="top" ALIGN="left"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">&#149;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="top"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD ALIGN="left" VALIGN="top"> <P ALIGN="left"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Supplemental Match provided to the named executive officers on the same basis as all other employees eligible for Supplemental Match; </FONT></P></TD></TR></TABLE>
<P STYLE="font-size:2px;margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">&nbsp;</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="5%"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="2%" VALIGN="top" ALIGN="left"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">&#149;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="top"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD ALIGN="left" VALIGN="top"> <P ALIGN="left"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Vested benefits accrued under the DB SERP and account balances held under the Deferred Compensation Plan as described above beginning on pages 67 and 70; and
</FONT></P></TD></TR></TABLE> <P STYLE="font-size:2px;margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">&nbsp;</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="5%"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="2%" VALIGN="top" ALIGN="left"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">&#149;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="top"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD ALIGN="left" VALIGN="top"> <P ALIGN="left"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Stock options which have vested and become exercisable prior to the employment termination or change in control. </FONT></P></TD></TR></TABLE> <P
STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">The payments and benefits described in the five bullet points above are referred to in the following discussion as the executive officer&#146;s &#147;vested
benefits.&#148; </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><I>Voluntary Resignation </I></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">We are not
obligated to pay amounts over and above vested benefits to a named executive officer who voluntarily resigns. Vested stock options may not be exercised after the named executive officer&#146;s resignation date unless the officer is age 55 or older,
as described in Treatment of Stock Options upon Retirement, Death or Disability below. Mr.&nbsp;West&#146;s vested benefits include his DB&nbsp;SERP benefit per the terms of his employment agreement. </FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><I>Discharge for Cause </I></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">If we terminate a named executive
officer&#146;s employment for Cause, we are not obligated to pay the officer any amounts over and above the vested benefits. The named executive officer&#146;s right to exercise vested options expires upon discharge for Cause, and amounts otherwise
payable under the DB SERP are subject to forfeiture at the Company&#146;s discretion. In general, a discharge will be for Cause if the executive has intentionally failed to perform his or her duties or engaged in illegal or gross misconduct that
harms the Company. Mr.&nbsp;West&#146;s vested benefits include his DB SERP benefit per the terms of his employment agreement. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><I>Death or Disability </I>
</FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">If an executive officer dies and has not met the vesting requirements to be eligible to receive a benefit from the DB SERP, no benefits are paid. Messrs.
West and Snyder were fully vested in their DB SERP benefits as of December&nbsp;31, 2008. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">A maximum monthly long-term disability benefit of $35,000 is
provided for Mr.&nbsp;West and $25,000 for all other named executive officers in the event of long-term disability. Long-term disability benefits are payable until age 65. Long-term disability benefits are offset by other benefits such as Social
Security. The maximum amount of the monthly long-term disability payments from all sources, assuming long-term disability on December&nbsp;31, 2008, is set forth in the tables below. The additional lump sum DB SERP amount that would be payable for
Ms.&nbsp;Buck and Messrs. West and </FONT>
</P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P>

<TD ALIGN="left" VALIGN="top"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="1">Mr.&nbsp;Snyder has exceeded the DB SERP age and service requirements and would receive no incremental amount if he became disabled. </FONT></TD></TR></TABLE> <P
STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><I>Treatment of Stock Options upon Retirement, Death or Disability </I></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">The
Incentive Plan provides that all vested stock options remain exercisable for five years following termination due to retirement after age 55, death or disability, but not beyond the original term of the option. Options that are not vested at the
time of retirement, death or disability will continue to vest throughout the five-year period following retirement, death or disability according to the original vesting schedule established at the grant date. The following table provides the number
of unvested stock options as of December&nbsp;31, 2008 that would have become vested and remained exercisable during the five-year period following death or disability, or retirement, if applicable, on December&nbsp;31, 2008, and the value of those
options based on the excess of the fair market value of our Common Stock on December&nbsp;31, 2008 over the option exercise price. Only Mr.&nbsp;Snyder was retirement eligible on December&nbsp;31, 2008. </FONT></P> <P
STYLE="font-size:12px;margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">&nbsp;</P>

<HR  SIZE="3" COLOR="#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">


 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P>
 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><I>Treatment of RSUs upon Retirement, Death or Disability </I> </FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Upon retirement any RSUs that are not vested are forfeited. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">A prorated
portion of any unvested RSU award vests upon death or disability. The prorated number of RSUs is based upon the number of full and partial calendar months from the grant date to the date of death or disability divided by the number of full and
partial calendar months from the grant date to the end of the restriction period multiplied by the number of RSUs originally granted. The following table summarizes the unvested RSU awards that would have vested on December&nbsp;31, 2008 if the
executive&#146;s employment terminated that day due to death or disability. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="font-size:12px;margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">&nbsp;</P>
<TABLE CELLSPACING="0" CELLPADDING="0" WIDTH="62%" BORDER="0" ALIGN="center">

<TR>
<TD WIDTH="3%" VALIGN="top" ALIGN="left"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="1">(2)</FONT></TD>
<TD ALIGN="left" VALIGN="top"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="1">Value of shares based on $34.74 closing price for our Common Stock on December&nbsp;31, 2008. </FONT></TD></TR></TABLE> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT
FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><I>Discharge Not for Cause; Resignation for Good Reason </I></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Our employment agreement with Mr.&nbsp;West obligates the
Company to pay severance benefits if we terminate his employment for reasons other than for Cause or if Mr.&nbsp;West resigns for Good Reason. Mr.&nbsp;West will have Good Reason to resign if there is a material breach of the employment agreement by
the Company, including a failure to maintain Mr.&nbsp;West in his current positions, adversely changing his authority or responsibilities, failing to pay or provide agreed-upon compensation and benefits, or giving notice to stop the daily renewal of
the term of the employment agreement. Mr.&nbsp;West must give the Company notice and an opportunity to cure the breach before resigning for Good Reason. The severance benefits payable to Mr.&nbsp;West are a lump sum equal to a pro rata AIP award for
the year of termination based on actual Company results plus two times his annual base salary and target AIP award for the year of termination, and continuation of health and other benefits for five years, subject to reduction for benefits received
from a subsequent employer. In addition, any unvested stock options held by Mr.&nbsp;West will remain outstanding and continue to vest during the two-year period following termination of employment. </FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">With respect to the named executive officers other than Mr.&nbsp;West, under the EBPP, we have agreed to two times salary paid in a lump sum if we terminate the
executive officer&#146;s active employment without Cause. These benefits are also payable if the executive officer resigns from active employment for Good Reason. Good Reason arises under the EBPP if we appoint a new </FONT>
</P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P>
 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">75 </FONT></P>

 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">
<FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Chief Executive Officer and, during the first two years of his or her tenure, the executive officer&#146;s position, authority, duties or responsibilities
are diminished or base salary is reduced. An applicable two-year period commenced December&nbsp;1, 2007 with Mr.&nbsp;West&#146;s appointment as our new Chief Executive Officer. If an executive officer&#146;s employment is terminated for reasons
other than for Cause or for Good Reason, the executive will be placed on a two-year leave of absence. During the two-year leave of absence, the executive officer&#146;s employment continues, so that he or she will continue to earn, vest or
participate in our benefit plans, contingent target AIP awards and previously granted stock options during the leave of absence period. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">The following
table summarizes the amount of severance benefits that would be payable to the named executive officer had his or her employment terminated on December&nbsp;31, 2008, under circumstances entitling the officer to severance benefits as described
above: </FONT></P> <P STYLE="font-size:12px;margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">&nbsp;</P>

<TD ALIGN="left" VALIGN="top"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="1">Mr.&nbsp;West&#146;s employment agreement provides for continuation of medical and dental coverage for a period of five years following discharge not for Cause or resignation for
Good Reason. The amount shown above includes that cost and the value of vision coverage for a period of two years. </FONT></TD></TR></TABLE> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">In addition, all stock
options outstanding at the time of termination of active employment will remain outstanding and continue to vest as if the executive officer&#146;s employment continued during the two-year leave of absence. The executive officer will not be entitled
to receive base salary, new stock option, contingent target PSU or RSU awards or other awards during the leave of absence. Information with respect to stock options held by each executive officer as of December&nbsp;31, 2008 appears in the
Outstanding Equity Awards table. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><I>Change in Control </I></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman"
SIZE="2">Special provisions apply if a change in control occurs. In general, a change in control will occur if the Milton Hershey School Trust no longer owns voting control of the Company and another person or group acquires 25% or more of the
combined voting power of our voting stock, there is an unwelcome change in a majority of the members of our Board, or, if after our stockholders approve a merger or similar business transaction or a sale of substantially all of our assets, the
Milton Hershey School Trust does not own voting control of the merged or acquiring company. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Our employment agreement with Mr.&nbsp;West provides that he
is entitled to the benefits of the EBPP if a change in control occurs. The EBPP provides the vesting and payment of the following benefits upon a change in control to each of the named executive officers: </FONT></P> <P
STYLE="font-size:12px;margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">&nbsp;</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">

<TD WIDTH="2%" VALIGN="top" ALIGN="left"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">&#149;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="top"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD ALIGN="left" VALIGN="top"> <P ALIGN="left"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">An AIP payment for the year of the change in control at the greater of target or the estimated payment based on actual performance to the date of the change in
control; </FONT></P></TD></TR></TABLE> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P>

<TD ALIGN="left" VALIGN="top"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="1">Amounts reflect vesting of PSUs for the cycle ended December&nbsp;31, 2008 at 100% target and a value per PSU of $38.23, the highest closing price for our Common Stock during the
last 60 days of 2008, vesting at target of the PSUs for the cycle ending December&nbsp;31, 2009 and one-third of the PSUs for the cycle ending December&nbsp;31, 2010, with a value per PSU of $34.74, the closing price of our Common Stock on the New
York Stock Exchange on December&nbsp;31, 2008, the last trading day of 2008. </FONT></TD></TR></TABLE> <P STYLE="font-size:6px;margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">&nbsp;</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="3%" VALIGN="top" ALIGN="left"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="1">(3)</FONT></TD>
<TD ALIGN="left" VALIGN="top"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="1">Totals reflect full vesting of DB SERP and more favorable early retirement discount factors as provided under the EBPP. Messrs. West and Snyder are fully vested in their DB SERP
benefit so no additional benefit is applicable. For Mr.&nbsp;Alfonso, the amount includes the vesting of his CLRP, DC SERP and other non-vested retirement benefits. </FONT></TD></TR></TABLE> <P
STYLE="font-size:6px;margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">&nbsp;</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="3%" VALIGN="top" ALIGN="left"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="1">(4)</FONT></TD>
<TD ALIGN="left" VALIGN="top"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="1">Reflects the value of unvested options that would vest upon a change in control based on the excess, if any, of the market value of our Common Stock of $34.74 on December&nbsp;31,
2008 over the exercise price for the options. Information regarding unvested options as of December&nbsp;31, 2008 can be found in the Outstanding Equity Awards table. </FONT></TD></TR></TABLE> <P
STYLE="font-size:6px;margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">&nbsp;</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="3%" VALIGN="top" ALIGN="left"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="1">(5)</FONT></TD>
<TD ALIGN="left" VALIGN="top"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="1">Reflects the value of unvested RSUs that would vest upon a change in control based on the market value of our Common Stock of $34.74 on December&nbsp;31, 2008, as well as the
accrued cash credits equivalent to dividends that would have been earned had the executive held Common Stock instead of RSUs. Information regarding unvested RSUs as of December&nbsp;31, 2008 can be found in the Outstanding Equity Awards table.
</FONT></TD></TR></TABLE> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P>
 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">77 </FONT></P>


<p Style='page-break-before:always'>
<HR  SIZE="3" COLOR="#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">

 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><I>Discharge Not for Cause or Resignation
for Good Reason after Change in Control </I></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">If the named executive officer&#146;s employment is terminated by the Company without Cause or by the
executive for Good Reason within two years after the change in control, we pay severance benefits to assist the executive in transitioning to new employment. Good Reason for this purpose means diminution of the executive&#146;s position, authority,
duties or responsibilities; a reduction in base salary; the requirement that the executive engage in substantially greater business travel; failure to pay current compensation or to continue in effect short- and long-term compensation and employee
and retirement benefits; or the failure to fund a grantor trust to support payment of amounts under the EBPP. The severance benefits under the EBPP for termination after a change in control in 2008 consist of: </FONT></P> <P
STYLE="font-size:12px;margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">&nbsp;</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; padding-bottom:8px; margin-top:-2px" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="5%"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="2%" VALIGN="top" ALIGN="left"> <P STYLE="line-height:95%; vertical-align:top"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">&#149;</FONT></P></TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="top"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD ALIGN="left" VALIGN="top"> <P STYLE="line-height:95%; vertical-align:top" ALIGN="left"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">A lump sum cash payment equal to two (or, if less, the number of full and fractional years from the date of termination
to the executive&#146;s 65</FONT><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="1"><SUP>th</SUP></FONT><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"> birthday, but not less than one) times the executive&#146;s salary and the highest AIP payment paid or payable during
the three years preceding the year of the change in control (but not less than the AIP target for the year of the change in control); </FONT></P></TD></TR></TABLE> <P STYLE="font-size:2px;margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">&nbsp;</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="5%"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="2%" VALIGN="top" ALIGN="left"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">&#149;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="top"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD ALIGN="left" VALIGN="top"> <P ALIGN="left"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Continuation of medical and other benefits for 24 months (or if less, the number of months until the executive attains age 65, but not less than 12 months), or
payment of the value of such benefits if continuation is not permitted under the terms of the applicable plan; </FONT></P></TD></TR></TABLE> <P STYLE="font-size:2px;margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">&nbsp;</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="5%"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="2%" VALIGN="top" ALIGN="left"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">&#149;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="top"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD ALIGN="left" VALIGN="top"> <P ALIGN="left"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Outplacement services up to $35,000 and reimbursement for financial and tax preparation services; </FONT></P></TD></TR></TABLE> <P
STYLE="font-size:2px;margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">&nbsp;</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="5%"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="2%" VALIGN="top" ALIGN="left"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">&#149;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="top"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD ALIGN="left" VALIGN="top"> <P ALIGN="left"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">For participants in the DB SERP, an enhanced benefit reflecting an additional two years&#146; credit; and </FONT></P></TD></TR></TABLE> <P
STYLE="font-size:2px;margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">&nbsp;</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="5%"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="2%" VALIGN="top" ALIGN="left"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">&#149;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="top"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD ALIGN="left" VALIGN="top"> <P ALIGN="left"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">For participants in the DC SERP, an enhanced benefit reflecting a cash payment equal to the applicable percentage rate multiplied by his or her annual base salary
and last annual incentive pay calculated as if such amounts were paid during the years in the executive&#146;s severance period. </FONT></P></TD></TR></TABLE> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">The
EBPP also provides for a gross-up payment should the executive be subject to the excise tax on golden parachutes due to the receipt of severance benefits or as a result of the payment or vesting of stock options upon the change in control. The table
below summarizes the severance payments, the tax gross-up payment and all other amounts that would have vested and become payable if a change in control occurred and the executive&#146;s employment terminated on December&nbsp;31, 2008. </FONT></P>
<P STYLE="font-size:12px;margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">&nbsp;</P>

<TD WIDTH="3%" VALIGN="top" ALIGN="left"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="1">(1)</FONT></TD>
<TD ALIGN="left" VALIGN="top"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="1">Reflects amount of health and welfare benefit continuation premium paid by the Company over a two-year period. </FONT></TD></TR></TABLE> <P
STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P>
 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">78 </FONT></P>


<p Style='page-break-before:always'>
<HR  SIZE="3" COLOR="#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">


 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P>

<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="3%" VALIGN="top" ALIGN="left"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="1">(2)</FONT></TD>
<TD ALIGN="left" VALIGN="top"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="1">Value of financial planning and tax preparation continuation for two years following termination of employment plus outplacement services of $35,000. </FONT></TD></TR></TABLE> <P
STYLE="font-size:6px;margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">&nbsp;</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="3%" VALIGN="top" ALIGN="left"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="1">(3)</FONT></TD>
<TD ALIGN="left" VALIGN="top"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="1">Reflects amount of enhanced DB SERP and lump sum amount of employer 401(k) matching amounts over a two-year period. For Mr.&nbsp;Alfonso, the value reflects the lump sum amount of
DC SERP, CLRP and employer 401(k) matching amounts over a two-year period. </FONT></TD></TR></TABLE> <P STYLE="font-size:6px;margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">&nbsp;</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="3%" VALIGN="top" ALIGN="left"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="1">(4)</FONT></TD>
<TD ALIGN="left" VALIGN="top"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="1">Gross-up payment for excise taxes for all named executive officers was determined using a transaction price of $34.74 and an individual tax rate of 40.61% for Mr.&nbsp;West,
Mr.&nbsp;Alfonso and Ms.&nbsp;Buck, 41.21% for Mr.&nbsp;Bilbrey and 41.61% for Mr.&nbsp;Snyder. This payment was determined assuming all executives were involuntarily terminated on December&nbsp;31, 2008; deemed to be &#147;disqualified
individuals&#148;; and subject to the golden parachute rules under section 280G of the Internal Revenue Code. </FONT></TD></TR></TABLE> <P STYLE="font-size:6px;margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">&nbsp;</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="3%" VALIGN="top" ALIGN="left"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="1">(5)</FONT></TD>
<TD ALIGN="left" VALIGN="top"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="1">Mr.&nbsp;West&#146;s employment agreement provides for continuation of medical and dental coverage for a period of five years following termination due to change in control. The
amount shown above includes that cost and the value of life insurance and vision coverage for a period of two years. </FONT></TD></TR></TABLE> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><B><A NAME="toc83500_23">
</A>SECTION 16(a) BENEFICIAL OWNERSHIP REPORTING COMPLIANCE </B></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><B>What is section 16(a) of the Securities Exchange Act of 1934? </B></FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Section&nbsp;16(a) of the Securities Exchange Act of 1934, as amended, requires our directors, executive officers and persons owning more than 10% of our outstanding
Common Stock or Class B Common Stock to file reports with the SEC showing their ownership and changes in ownership of Hershey securities. Based solely on our examination of these reports and on written representations provided to us, it is our
opinion that all reports for 2008 have been timely filed. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><B><A NAME="toc83500_24"></A>CERTAIN TRANSACTIONS AND RELATIONSHIPS
</B></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><B>What is being disclosed in this section? </B></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">SEC
regulations require that we disclose any transaction, or series of similar transactions, since the beginning of 2008, or any contemplated transactions, in which the Company was or is to be a participant, in which the amount involved exceeds $120,000
and in which any of the following persons had or will have a direct or indirect material interest: </FONT></P> <P STYLE="font-size:12px;margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">&nbsp;</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="5%"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="2%" VALIGN="top" ALIGN="left"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">&#149;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="top"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD ALIGN="left" VALIGN="top"> <P ALIGN="left"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Our directors or nominees for director; </FONT></P></TD></TR></TABLE> <P STYLE="font-size:2px;margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">&nbsp;</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="5%"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="2%" VALIGN="top" ALIGN="left"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">&#149;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="top"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD ALIGN="left" VALIGN="top"> <P ALIGN="left"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Our executive officers; </FONT></P></TD></TR></TABLE> <P STYLE="font-size:2px;margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">&nbsp;</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="5%"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="2%" VALIGN="top" ALIGN="left"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">&#149;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="top"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD ALIGN="left" VALIGN="top"> <P ALIGN="left"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Persons owning more than 5% of any class of our outstanding voting securities; or </FONT></P></TD></TR></TABLE> <P
STYLE="font-size:2px;margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">&nbsp;</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="5%"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="2%" VALIGN="top" ALIGN="left"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">&#149;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="top"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD ALIGN="left" VALIGN="top"> <P ALIGN="left"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">The immediate family members of any of the persons identified in the preceding three bullets. </FONT></P></TD></TR></TABLE> <P
STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">The SEC refers to these types of transactions as <I>related person transactions</I> and to the persons listed in the bullets as <I>related persons</I>. The SEC is
concerned about related person transactions because such transactions, if not properly monitored, may present risks of conflicts of interest or the appearance of conflicts of interest. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT
FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><B>Does the Company have a policy to review, approve or ratify related person transactions? </B></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Our Board has adopted a
Related Person Transaction Policy that governs the review, approval or ratification of related person transactions. The Related Person Transaction Policy may be viewed on our corporate website, www.hersheys.com, in the Investor Relations section.
</FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P>
 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">79 </FONT></P>


<p Style='page-break-before:always'>
<HR  SIZE="3" COLOR="#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">

 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Under our policy, each related person
transaction, and any significant amendment or modification to a related person transaction, must be reviewed and approved or ratified by a committee of our Board composed solely of independent directors who have no interest in the transaction. We
refer to each such committee as a Reviewing Committee. The policy also permits the disinterested members of the full Board to act as a Reviewing Committee. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman"
SIZE="2">The Board has designated the Governance Committee as the Reviewing Committee primarily responsible for the administration of the Related Person Transaction Policy. In addition, the Board has designated special Reviewing Committees to
oversee certain transactions involving the Company and Hershey Trust Company, the Milton Hershey School Trust and companies owned by the Milton Hershey School Trust. To learn more about these special Reviewing Committees, please see the answer to
the fourth question in this section, below. Finally, the policy provides that the Compensation and Executive Organization Committee will review and approve, or review and recommend to the Board for approval, any employment relationship or
transaction involving an executive officer of the Company and any related compensation. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">When reviewing, approving or ratifying a related person
transaction, the Reviewing Committee will examine several things, including the approximate dollar value of the transaction and all material facts about the related person&#146;s interest in, or relationship to, the transaction. If the related
person transaction involves an outside director or nominee for director, the Reviewing Committee may also consider whether the transaction would compromise the director&#146;s status as an &#147;independent director,&#148; &#147;outside
director&#148; or &#147;non-employee director&#148; under our Corporate Governance Guidelines and rules and regulations of the New York Stock Exchange, the Internal Revenue Code or the Securities Exchange Act of 1934, as amended. </FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><B>Was the Company a participant in any related person transactions in 2008, or does the Company currently contemplate being a participant in any related person
transactions in 2009, involving our directors, executive officers or their immediate family members? </B></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">We were not a participant in any related person
transactions in 2008, and do not currently contemplate being a participant in any related person transactions in 2009, involving our directors, executive officers or their immediate family members. </FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><B>Was the Company a participant in any related person transactions in 2008, or does the Company currently contemplate being a participant in any related person
transactions in 2009, involving a stockholder owning more than 5% of any class of the Company&#146;s securities? </B></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">We engage in certain transactions
with Milton Hershey School, the Milton Hershey School Trust and companies owned by the Milton Hershey School Trust. As discussed in the next question, many of these transactions are immaterial, ordinary course transactions and are not considered
related person transactions. However, from time to time we also engage in certain related person transactions with the Milton Hershey School Trust and its affiliates. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT
FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Our Board has directed that a special Reviewing Committee composed of the directors elected by the holders of the Common Stock voting separately as a class and having no affiliation with the Milton Hershey School
Trust or its affiliates review and make recommendations to the Board regarding these transactions. However, the Board has also directed that if there are no directors on the Board who were elected by the holders of our Common Stock voting
separately, such transactions will be reviewed by the independent members of the Executive Committee who have no affiliation with the Milton Hershey School Trust or its affiliates. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT
SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P>
 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">80 </FONT></P>


<p Style='page-break-before:always'>
<HR  SIZE="3" COLOR="#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">


 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P>
 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">The Reviewing Committee, composed of the directors elected by the holders of the Common Stock voting separately as a
class, approved two real estate transactions with the Milton Hershey School Trust in 2008. One of the transactions was completed in 2008. We expect the second transaction to be completed in 2009. Those transactions are as follows: </FONT></P> <P
STYLE="font-size:12px;margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">&nbsp;</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="5%"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="2%" VALIGN="top" ALIGN="left"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">&#149;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="top"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD ALIGN="left" VALIGN="top"> <P ALIGN="left"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">On December&nbsp;23, 2008, we sold to the Milton Hershey School Trust a 14.5 acre parcel of land containing an 80,000 square foot distribution facility for
$5,836,500. The property is located in Hershey, Pennsylvania. Following the sale, we leased the facility back from the Milton Hershey School Trust for a term expiring in June 2011. We have the right to extend the lease for two additional one-year
terms. Rent for the initial term is approximately $600,000, or $20,000 per month, plus operating costs, maintenance and property taxes. If we elect to extend the lease, rent for the second term will be $247,200, or $20,600 per month and for the
third term will be $254,400, or $21,200 per month, plus operating costs, maintenance and property taxes. Total rent for all three lease terms, if applicable, would be $1,101,600, plus operating costs, maintenance and property taxes. We originally
intended to sell this property to another buyer; however, the property was subject to a right of first refusal in favor of an affiliate of the Milton Hershey School Trust. The right of first refusal gave the affiliate of the Milton Hershey School
Trust the right to purchase the property from us at a price and on terms agreed to by us and another purchaser if such an agreement was ever reached. The affiliate informed us shortly after we entered into an agreement with the other buyer that it
had assigned its right of first refusal to the Milton Hershey School Trust and that the Milton Hershey School Trust would purchase the property. Prior to putting the property on the market for sale, we retained an independent appraiser to determine
its fair market value. The final purchase price was arrived at through negotiations with the initial buyer and was substantially similar to the fair market value determined by the independent appraiser. </FONT></P></TD></TR></TABLE> <P
STYLE="font-size:2px;margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">&nbsp;</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="5%"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="2%" VALIGN="top" ALIGN="left"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">&#149;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="top"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD ALIGN="left" VALIGN="top"> <P ALIGN="left"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">In the transaction expected to be completed in 2009, we would convey to the Milton Hershey School Trust a small parcel of land we own in Hershey, Pennsylvania. The
Milton Hershey School Trust, in turn, would convey to us an adjacent parcel of land of similar size owned by the Milton Hershey School Trust. The exchange is being made to better align the boundaries of other lands each party owns in the same
vicinity. Each parcel is less than one-fourth acre in size. The properties are considered to be of equal value and therefore an independent appraisal was not obtained. </FONT></P></TD></TR></TABLE> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT
FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Except as described above, the Company did not participate in any related person transactions in 2008, and does not currently expect to participate in any related person transactions in 2009, involving a stockholder
owning more than 5% of any class of the Company&#146;s securities. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P>
 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">81 </FONT></P>


<p Style='page-break-before:always'>
<HR  SIZE="3" COLOR="#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">

 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><B>Did the Company engage in other
transactions with the Milton Hershey School Trust or its affiliates during 2008? </B></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">During 2008, we engaged in transactions in the ordinary course of our
business with Milton Hershey School, the Milton Hershey School Trust, and companies owned by the Milton Hershey School Trust. These transactions involved the sale or purchase of goods and services. The transactions were primarily with Hershey
Entertainment&nbsp;&amp; Resorts Company, a company that is wholly-owned by the Milton Hershey School Trust. All sales and purchases were made on terms and at prices we believe were generally available in the marketplace and were in amounts that are
not material to us or to the Milton Hershey School Trust. Therefore, they are not related person transactions and do not have to be approved under our Related Person Transaction Policy. However, because of our relationship with the Milton Hershey
